channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Defying West, Putin Signs Treaty to Annex Crimea
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he was reversing what he described as a historical mistake, declaring, “Crimea has always been an integral part of Russia in the hearts and minds of people.”
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS, ELLEN BARRY and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: People in Simferopol, Ukraine, watched an address by President Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday.

item.title: Developer’s Collapse Adds to China Concerns
item.description: Weak housing prices for February add to the debate over the country’s commitment to economic reforms.
item.category: Zhejiang Xingrun Real Estate Investment Company
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH

item.title: In Poland, Biden Promises Allies Protection
item.description: In meetings with the leaders of Poland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. aims to shore up the NATO alliance.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: German Court Validates Participation in Euro Zone Bailout Fund
item.description: The decision allows Germany to contribute to the European Stability Mechanism, provided that lawmakers are consulted on major contributions.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Andreas Vosskuhle, president of Germany's Federal Constitutional Court, announces the ruling on Tuesday.

item.title: Seven Migrants Die Trying to Reach Greece
item.description: Eight people were rescued and two were missing after their boat capsized while crossing the Aegean Sea from Turkey.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: India Ink: India to Appeal Milan Ruling in Canceled Helicopter Deal
item.description: India is trying to recover 278 million euros in bank guarantees in a deal that was scrapped after top officials at AgustaWestland and its parent, Finmeccanica, were arrested on bribery charges last year.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Giuseppe Orsi, then chairman and chief executive of Italy's state-controlled defense group Finmeccanica, in Rome, on Oct. 18, 2012.

item.title: Tourism Dollars Dry Up, Alongside Crimea’s Bank Funds
item.description: A continuing lack of visitors is a chilling prospect in a place beloved as a vacation playground since czarist times.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: People stood in line outside a bank in Simferopol on Wednesday. Banks have been imposing severe restrictions on withdrawals.

item.title: Afghan President Chooses Tajik Leader as New Deputy
item.description: In nominating a Tajik former interior minister as vice president, President Hamid Karzai preserved the political and ethnic balance at the top of Afghanistan’s government.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: New U.S. Ambassador To China Gets a Fast Start
item.description: The new American ambassador to China, Max Baucus, visited the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Tuesday morning to present a copy of his credentials, a formality that allowed him to meet with journalists at the United States Embassy in the afternoon.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Ambassador Max Baucus briefed journalists on Tuesday at the U.S. Embassy in Beijing.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 16 in Northern Afghanistan
item.description: The bombing Tuesday, in a bazaar in the capital of Faryab Province, was the latest major attack in the lead-up to presidential elections next month.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and HARIS KAKAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Safe Place for Unwanted Babies Is Overwhelmed
item.description: When Guangzhou set up its first “baby hatch,” where parents can safely give away infants they feel they cannot raise, the babies poured in. With more than it could handle, it has temporarily shut down.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: People walking past a drop-off point for abandoned babies in Tianjin, China.

item.title: Nuclear Talks With Iran Resume
item.description: Iran calls for world powers to fulfill promises as negotiators meet in Vienna on Tuesday, under the shadow of international tensions over Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Another Kindergarten Closed After Report of Drugging Children
item.description: A kindergarten in a third Chinese province has been shut down for giving children daily doses of an antiviral drug without their parents’ knowledge or consent.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Beijing Says No Chinese Passengers Were Involved in Jet’s Disappearance
item.description: China on Tuesday ruled out the possibility that any of its nationals on Flight 370 were terrorists or malcontents who tried to seize the plane.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: South Korea Prepares to Return Chinese Soldiers’ Remains
item.description: South Korea plans to repatriate the remains of more than 400 Chinese soldiers killed during the Korean War, a sign of China’s increasing focus on remembering its war dead.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers wrapped the remains of Chinese war dead before placing them in coffins for their journey home.

item.title: Three Years of Strife and Cruelty Put Syria in Free Fall
item.description: At the start of the fourth year since Syrians rose up in a peaceful movement that turned to arms, a snapshot of the country presents the harsh truth that Syria’s descent is only accelerating.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Syrians crossed into northern Iraq at a border point in Dahuk Province in August. The United Nations says 2.5 million Syrians have fled into nearby countries.

item.title: Joseph Fan Zhongliang, ‘Underground’ Bishop of Shanghai, Dies at 95
item.description: Bishop Fan was arrested in 1955 during a crackdown on Christianity in China and spent more than two decades in prison and labor camps.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: The Cardinal Kung Foundation, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Joseph Fan Zhongliang was appointed bishop of Shanghai by Pope John Paul II in 2000.

item.title: Samuel W. Lewis, Envoy to Israel at Time of Camp David, Dies at 83
item.description: After being instrumental in the accords during the Carter administration, Mr. Lewis was asked to stay on when President Ronald Reagan took office in 1981.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Samuel W. Lewis, right, had diplomatic posts in Italy, Brazil and Afghanistan, but the highlight was his tenure in Tel Aviv, from 1977 to 1985.

item.title: Tension Is Growing as Families of Flight 370 Passengers Hold Vigil
item.description: In a Beijing hotel, expressions of exasperation with ever-changing stories from Malaysian officials.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Family members of passengers on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 voted Monday to talk directly with Malaysian government officials.

item.title: Pilots’ Possible Role in Flight 370 Vanishing ‘Unthinkable’ to Friends
item.description: The two men at the controls of Flight 370 led ordinary lives that revolved around family and flying, those who knew them said.
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Catholic Bishop Who Spent Decades in Prison Dies in Shanghai
item.description: Bishop Joseph Fan Zhongliang, who was imprisoned for more than two decades in China and spent his final years under house arrest, died on Sunday, a Roman Catholic organization said.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: The Cardinal Kung Foundation/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: World Briefing: After a Final Challenge, Election Officials Declare a Winner in El Salvador
item.description: After election officials turned aside complaints of fraud in the March 9 presidential election, Salvador Sánchez Cerén, 69, a former leftist guerrilla commander in the country’s 12-year civil war, was officially declared the victor on Sunday night.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: World Briefing: China Snubs U.N.’s North Korea Report
item.description: China on Monday dismissed a United Nations report accusing North Korea of committing crimes against humanity.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Morsi’s Son Faces Drug Charges in Egypt
item.description: Egyptian prosecutors said Monday that Abdullah Morsi, the youngest son of former President Mohamed Morsi would be tried on charges of drug use and possession, an accusation his family dismisses as an attempt to tarnish their image.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Lost Jet’s Path Seen as Altered via Computer
item.description: The first turn that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its route was entered into a computer system, most likely by someone in the plane’s cockpit, American officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: A Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777-200ER, flight 318 to Beijing, sat on the tarmac Monday at Kuala Lumpur International Airport. Flight 318 replaces 370, retired out of respect to the passengers and crew of the missing plane.
